title: History of R
text:
A simple history of R.
See this site for a longer history with fewer pictures.


Before R there was S
“S is a language that was developed by John Chambers and others at the old Bell Telephone Laboratories”



John Chambers at Stanford




S got bought and sold
Here’s a book on S







1996-2000 R is release for free
Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman of the university of Auckland Developed it.


Ross Ihaka

Photo by Kristina D.C. Hoeppner from Wellington, New Zealand - Ross Ihaka, CC BY-SA 2.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=37005667


Robert Gentleman



Robert Gentleman


Photo by Aneesulrehman - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=89993843


Why is it called R?


CRAN
Comprehensive R Archive Network
They manage all R updates and R packages. There are currently 19897 packages.
They put on the UseR! conference
There’s an R magazine
This is the CRAN team


Who made the tidyverse





Photo by By Hadley Wickham - Private correspondence, CC BY-SA 4.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=46810731


Who makes RStudio?


Started in 2009 as RStudio
The tidyverse comes out in 2016
Renamed Posit last year.
Offers Python Support




Things lots of people know about R
Default Colors palmerpenguins mtcars

Other things






To activate colors





Some students are not getting “red” to be red. Try this: Tools menu > global options > code > display > “enable preview of named and hex colors
If that doesn’t work, maybe its a bug?

title: Making Data Frames
text:
Weather



Vectors
Make three vectors with the day of the month, the weather and temperature.

day <- c(9, 10,11,12,13,14,15)
weather <- c()
temperature <- c()



Uniqueness

unique()
unique(weather)



Make a dataframe

Week_in_sept <- data.frame(day,weather,temperature)



Let’s take a look

Week_in_sept


glimpse(Week_in_sept)
head(): returns first 6 rows
tails(): returns last 6 rows
names(): returns the coloumn names
nrow(): returns the number of rows
ncol(): returns the number of columns



Renaming columns
Save the new column names as a vector and use the names() function.
Weekdays <- c(“Sunday”,“Monday”,“Tuesday”,“Wednesday”….)
names(Week_in_sept) <- Weekdays


Columns
We can use the $ to access columns as vectors Week_in_sept$Monday
Let’s do table() on Monday


A dataset

Columns are variables
Rows are observations
Individual entries are called values
The data we will deal with in this course is rectangular.


Metadata
This is the data about our data.
Sometimes a data dictionary comes with our data.
When data comes in a package we can use the ? operator.
Metadata deals with provenance.
Descriptive Data deals with the contents of the data.
Let’s consider ChickWeight and its metadata


Credits
Weather map- https://weather.com/forecast/news/2014-10-31-national-forecast-20141009
Data Frame Image- Grolemund, Garrett, and Hadley Wickham. n.d. R for Data Science. Accessed March 31, 2019. https://r4ds.had.co.nz/.

title: Data Ethics
section: Algorithms Reflect the bais of their creator
text:
Algorithms Reflect the bais of their creator

A piece of data itself has no positive or negative moral value, but the way we manipulate it does. It’s hard to imagine a more contentious project than programing ethics into our algorithms; to do otherwise, however, and allow algorithms to monitor themselves, is to invite the quicksand of moral equivalence.

title: Nic Schwab
text: Nicholas Schwab is a visiting lecturer in Statistical and Data Sciences. He is a tenured professor at Holyoke Community College. When not teaching data science, he enjoys rock climbing, running, and reading children’s books to his kids.
